She had attended a party the night of June 22 with her brother and her boyfriend. After an argument, she left by herself to walk home. According to Mescall, three people heard Oakeley’s cries for help around 8:42 p.m. that night. “The witness said they heard her scream and looked out into the street,” Mescall said at the time. “Then they heard her say, ‘I’ve been stabbed’ and she collapsed.” Oakeley died during surgery at University of New Mexico Hospital from numerous stab wounds to the torso, Mescall said. One witness claimed to have seen the offender. “We got some pretty detailed information,” Mescall said. The eye-witness said the suspect was an Hispanic male, 20-24 years old, five feet seven to five feet nine inches tall, weighing about 140 pounds, medium build with short, dark brown hair. The suspect was said to be wearing a white T-shirt, faded blue jeans and white tennis sneakers with a black stripe down the sides. Despite having a description and a police artist rendering of a suspect at the time, the case went cold for more than three decades – until Apodaca’s arrest this week. President Joe Biden announced on Monday that his administration will block federal oil and gas leasing within a 10-mile buffer zone around Chaco Canyon, a sacred Indigenous site in New Mexico. This comes due to methane’s critical role in advancing the warming of the atmosphere, with emissions having the potential to trap about 80 times as much heat as carbon dioxide in the first 20 years following the initial emissions release.
